text: this is what the fight against so-called
Islamic States has done to Ramadi six
months of brutal jihadi rule a
government offensive and coalition
airstrikes have devastated the city we
set off with Iraqi Special Forces to see
what the victory they claimed a week ago
looks like as we push into the center it
is clear that the battle for Ramadi is
far from over
this is the frontline in Iraq swore
against is the building used to be a
school but guns have now replaced
students the soldiers say they've
regained much of the city but the fight
is still going on and is militants still
control parts of the center their flags
are still flying just a few hundred
yards from here and resistance is stiff
peer through the snipers window and you
see the Iraqi flag but look to the right
the black banners of Islamic state
flying defiant government troops say
fighting is is the hardest of all
battles much of the frontline is rigged
with explosives and is is an
unpredictable enemy the West has trained
Iraqi soldiers for this fight the US
Britain and their partners are
conducting airstrikes in support the
support from coalition forces is
important to us because without them we
would suffer a lot more casualties
an airstrike is called in as families
emerge from the front lines Iraqi troops
taking them to safety
gorgey Amitabh says her house was blown
up she told me that she and her husband
were taken by the jihadis and used as
human shields we were stuck for 10 days
each time there was bombing our homes
would shake we had no food no bread no
water we were terrified a warm meal and
the first taste of freedom boom our maid
escaped with their children still
traumatized the mother tells me how is
ruled their lives what they did to us
was terrible we were not allowed out
without a man and were forced to wear
the niqab we were not even allowed to
use mobile phones victory is still days
away here but the war against Islamic
state in Iraq will not end in Ramadi it
has only just begun
there will be more hard fighting as
soldiers prepare to move to tougher
battlefields democracy BBC News Ramadi
